Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: Inexperienced staff are about to run a hazardous batch without understanding safety protocols.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, a smile tugging at my lips as I read his message: “Let’s pick a night for our date this week. I miss you.” We’d both been so busy, but finally, our schedules lined up. I could almost feel the warmth of his hand in mine, the easy laughter we shared over coffee. I wanted to be there, to give him the time and attention he deserved.

But just as I started to reply, my work phone buzzed. A panicked message from the plant: the new staff were about to start a batch on the old press, and no one had shown them the safety protocols. My heart thudded. If I didn’t step in, someone could get hurt. They needed me to walk them through the process, to make sure everything was safe.

I stared at both screens, feeling the weight of expectation from both sides. My boyfriend wanted me present, attentive, loving. My job demanded vigilance, responsibility, expertise. I could feel the tension coil in my chest, torn between being the girlfriend he needed and the repairer my team depended on.
